Award.AwardTitle: US-Jordan Advanced Studies Institute: Water in an Arid Land, the Engineered Water Cycle in Jordan
Award.AbstractNarration:
1239820
Gough

This project supports an Advance Study Institute by Dr. Heidi Gough, Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering at the University of Washington, Seattle and Dr. Muna Abu-Dalo, Jordan University of Science and Technology, Irbid, Jordan. They plan to organize a three-week workshop and course on Water in Arid Land, The Engineered Cycle in Jordan. It is scheduled for August-September 2012 and will include US and Jordanian students. The ASI will provide opportunity for study of sustainability and water in an arid country within the context of civil and environmental engineering disciplines; link the specialties of water resource, drinking water, desalination, and wastewater treatment within a single program, and focus on students early in their education path with the expectation that the program experience will influence their future career development.
Intellectual Merit: Water is a scarce commodity, and many parts of the world receive very little annual rainfall, including much of the developing world. Water is predicted to become increasingly more difficult to obtain, and providing access to clean water is listed among the engineering grand challenges. Water collection, drinking water treatment, and wastewater treatment are inherently different in arid regions than in water-rich regions. This project will help future engineers be equipped with knowledge related to these differences. The Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan will serve as the backdrop for an Advanced Studies Institute exploring the engineered water cycle in an arid region. The institute will examine the engineered water cycle in Jordan by studying (1) the current and historic water resources in Jordan, (2) drinking water treatment and distribution in Jordan including the use of cisterns and desalination, (3) treatment of concentrated wastewater including efforts for safe reuse, and (4) plans in Jordan for meeting future challenges. The program will partner this Advanced Studies Institute with a University of Washington Study Abroad Exploration Seminar Program.
Broader Impacts: The targeted participants for the program are engineering and hydrology undergraduate and early graduate students from US (predominately University of Washington) and Jordanian universities. Because this young generation of scientists and engineers are expected to be at the fore-front of technological solutions and decisions that are anticipated to impact society in the next 30 to 50 years,
targeting this population now will provide cross-disciplinary training to provide a greater breadth to their
educational and future professional experiences. Two members of the organizing committee are from an underrepresented group (women in science), and underrepresented groups will be encouraged to apply. A webpage developed as part of the institute will serve to increase recognition of the institute, and it is planned that this first year will serve as a pilot project for a self-sustaining program that will continue in future years. It is further anticipated that the program will increase teaching and research collaboration between the two sponsoring universities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Water is a scarce commodity. Many parts of the world receive very little annual rainfall, including much of the developing world. Supplying clean water to world populations has been designated a grand challenge by the National Academy of Engineering. However, water collection, drinking water treatment, and wastewater treatment in arid regions are inherently different from water-rich regions. Seasonal variation in precipitation necessitates different strategies for water storage, harvesting, and decision making. Additionally, higher salt and dissolved solids concentrations impact water quality in dry regions, influencing efficacy of drinking water treatments. Higher strength wastewater is also encountered in arid regions where infiltration of groundwater is less likely to dilute sewage flows, and wastewater effluent represents a greater fraction of the flow in water bodies receiving effluent. These are challenges not often discussed in traditional engineering curriculum.

An institute was established in 2012 to examine the engineered water cycle in an arid climate using the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan as a case study location. Jordan is among the 10 scarcest water nations in the world and has an established water infrastructure system that is currently strained due to declining water resources and increased populations. The institute was conducted on-site in Jordan for 3 weeks as a partnership between the University of Washington (UW) and the Jordan University for Science and Technology (JUST). Eight (8) students from UW and 4 students from JUST participated in 2012, which was coordinated by one faculty member from each university (Dr. Heidi Gough and Dr. Muna Abu-Dalo) and a teaching assistant from UW. During the three week program participants visited 5 water/wastewater treatment facilities and heard from 10 expert guest lecturers representing academics, industry, and government. Examples of ancient water engineering were explored through visits to the ruins of 2 ancient Roman Decapolis cities and the Nabatean city of Petra (circa 170 BC – 200 AD). Learning was reinforced through group discussions, problem sets, and student projects.

In addition to the engineering curriculum, culture exchange was incorporated as an integral part of the institute. Environmental engineering is an international field and ABET certifications of Civil Engineering undergraduate programs require inclusion of learning outcomes in “global competency”. Study abroad has been shown as an effective way to increase cultural and global competency. However, study abroad opportunities for engineering students are rare and have not historically been considered as important components of undergraduate engineering programs. To enhance cultural exchange, all assignments were conducted in small groups combined between the two groups of students. Groups were assigned at random to mimic the environment encountered on professional engineering teams working on international projects. To further deepen the cultural exchange, students in the two joint programs shared living spaces, travel accommodations, and eating facilities for the duration of the institute.

A variety of students participated in the course. From the UW, 5 of the 8 students were female and 3 students were from recognized minority groups so that through NSF-sponsorship the US-based group had an opportunity to portray a more representative cross-section of American engineering education than is typically portrayed in popular media. Additionally, from JUST 2 of the 4 students were female. Both the faculty involved in the program were female who are earlier in the career paths.
